sect1.title: CASE 15
sect1.para: The patient was a 39-year-old male with poorly controlled diabetes who presented with diabetic ketoacidosis and a right-sided headache with vision loss in his right eye. On physical exam, the right pupil was nonreactive. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a poorly visualized right ophthalmic artery. He was taken to the operating room (OR) emergently, where extensive debridement was performed on the right sinuses.

listitem.para: 1. Why was the patient taken emergently to the OR?

sect1.para: Multiple frozen section biopsies were done during the procedure.

listitem.para: 2. What is a frozen section biopsy? Why were several done during the procedure?

sect1.para: The procedure was significant for a lack of bleeding during the initial stages of the debridement. A biopsy of the sella region of the brain is seen in Fig. 15.1. A culture from the same region of the brain is seen in Fig. 15.2.

listitem.para: 3. What agent is most likely causing this patient’s infection? How did the patient likely become infected?
4. Why was there little bleeding during the initial stages of surgery? (See Fig. 15.1 for a clue.)
5. What risk factor did this patient have for the development of his infection?

listitem.para: 6. What is the appropriate treatment for this infection?
7. What other infections may be seen with the organism causing this infection, and in what patient population are they likely to be seen?

sect1.para: 1. The clinical presentation of a poorly controlled diabetic with localized headache and evidence of vision loss is consistent with a disease called rhinocerebral mucormycosis (1). This infection is associated with significant mortality, and prompt surgical intervention is imperative because of its highly destructive nature.

2. A frozen section biopsy is essentially as it sounds. A biopsy is obtained and the tissue is frozen at –20 to –30°C in a cryostat device; the tissue is then cut into thin sections, stained, and examined by a pathologist (2). The time from receipt of the tissue specimen in the laboratory to diagnosis by the pathologist is ~30 minutes. However, that turnaround time may be extended if the diagnosis is not obvious and additional consultations with other pathologists are necessary. Because of the time frozen sections take, they are only used in limited clinical situations, such as ensuring clear margins in tumor removal. Multiple biopsies were done in this case because the surgeon was debriding necrotic tissue. The surgeon’s goal was to debride sufficiently to remove all infected tissue but limit the amount of tissue removed from the brain so as not affect neural function.

3. The identification of broad, ribbon-like hyphae with few septations (pauciseptate) on histology is consistent with molds in the order Mucorales. In Fig. 15.1, characteristic hyphae (yellow arrows) are noted within the blood vessel (red arrows) and highlight the angioinvasive nature of these pathogens. The two most common Mucorales genera are Rhizopus and Mucor. Clinically encountered Mucorales are resistant to the antifungal agent voriconazole used to treat most mold infections so their accurate identification is critical. The culture of tissue obtained from a brain biopsy seen in Fig. 15.2, demonstrates characteristic fluffy, white, fast-growing (2 to 4 days) colonies with aerial hyphae that extend upwards to lift the lid off the plate. Invasion into the brain tissue is an ominous finding. This patient died 4 days after this surgery. Mortality from this infection varies, depending on the stage of infection at which the individual presents, but can be as high as 100% in certain immunosuppressed hosts.

The Mucorales are ubiquitous saprophytes in natural environments, especially decomposing organic matter. The organism reproduces by the production of conidia (spores). Individuals become infected by inhaling conidia from the environment. The conidia are trapped in the nasal turbinate. In most instances they are cleared, but in poorly controlled diabetics or people with malignancy, the conidia can germinate into fungal hyphae that may invade the sinuses and surrounding tissues. Because these fungi are both angioinvasive and rapidly growing, they can cause rapid necrosis in the tissue they infect by occluding blood vessels and causing thrombosis.

4. In necrotic (infected) regions, blood flow is lost because of the occlusion and thrombosis in the vessel. Blockage of the right ophthalmic artery was believed to be responsible for the patient’s loss of vision in the right eye.

5. Invasive rhinocerebral fungal infections are most common in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (1). Experimental evidence suggests that the blood and tissues of patients in ketoacidosis contain more glucose and free iron, a key fungal nutrient available for the growth of the Mucorales. Well-controlled diabetics rarely develop this infection. It may also be seen in individuals receiving corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive biologics and those with hematologic malignancies, especially those who have received human stem cell transplants.
6. Treatment of rhinocerebral mucormycosis is three-pronged (3).

listitem.para: Surgical debridement of the necrotic area; repeated frozen sections may be taken to determine when the necrotic area has been completely debrided. Delay in surgical debridement, especially if the infection progresses into the brain, is associated with high mortality.
Prompt control of ketoacidosis and hyperglycemia.
Treatment with liposomal amphotericin B. The Mucorales are resistant to the most commonly used antifungal agents, the azoles and echinocandins.

sect1.para: 7. Four forms of infection may be seen:

listitem.para: Pulmonary mucormycosis occurs primarily in patients with hematologic malignancies with granulocytopenia(1). It may disseminate and has high mortality, especially in patients with prolonged granulocytopenia. It is the most common cause of serious infection due to the Mucorales.

Cutaneous mucormycosis can occur when the conidia of the mold contaminate a wound in a granulocytopenic patient or a patient with full-thickness burns or deep abrasions. Patients often have black eschars due to necrosis. The infected wound may have a fluffy white appearance similar to that seen in Fig. 15.2 due to the formation of a mycelial mat as the fungus grows on the tissue.
Keratitis may occur when organic matter containing Mucorales is introduced into an ocular wound following trauma (4). This is a sight-threatening infection if diagnosis and treatment are delayed.

COVID-associated mucormycosis occurs when severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2-mediated damage to the sinonasal mucosa and immunosuppressive treatments aimed to dampen viral pneumonia enable inhaled conidia to germinate into hyphae and cause rhinocerebral mucormycosis(5).
Rhinocerebral mucormycosis is most commonly seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes and ketoacidosis.

Rhinocerebral mucormycosis begins when fungal conidia (spores) are inhaled and trapped in the nasal turbinates or sinuses. If conditions are favorable, such as with diabetic ketoacidosis or neutropenia, conidia germinate into hyphae, which invade tissues and blood vessels, resulting in local ischemia and tissue necrosis. Extension to the brain is associated with very high mortality.

The most common fungi that cause rhinocerebral mucormycosis are Rhizopus and Mucor. On culture they grow rapidly, with a fluffy white appearance. Microscopically, the hyphal elements are broad and ribbon-like with very few septations (pauciseptate). They are referred to as “lid lifters” because they will rapidly take up all the space inside an agar plate (see Fig. 15.2).
Treatment is multipronged, requiring aggressive surgical debridement, correction of ketoacidosis and immunosuppression, and treatment with antifungal agents.
